events.target_title: [Feature request] Read only mode

note.body:
I think the easiest way to implement this is to make the safe *read-only* by default. Opening an entry could reveal either a master *Edit* button for every field in the entry, or an *Edit* button next to every field. The former can even be in the *HeaderBar* since when viewing an entry there are very few buttons anyway.

A question that arises is about the layout of the entry itself. Are users shown input fields, although visibly inactive? Or a something more along the lines of the *About* page in *GNOME Settings*?

events.target_title: Application name collides with that of another well known open-source password manager

note.body:
"Secrets" is a bit ambiguous - what is it protecting? Files? Passwords? Contacts? "Password Vault" seems more straightforward for a password manager, and you know exactly what it does when you see the name.

Another option is simply "Passwords". On one hand, removing the second word might reduce the implied feeling of safety/security, despite the icon. On the other hand, Apple's "Keychain" implies more *handiness* than *security*, so it might not be an issue.

note.body:
As an embedded developer, let me add my grain of salt: 

1.  millions of devices (smartphone, tablets, TV, IoT in general) use one of uClibc, uClibc-ng or bionic (Android) libc.
1.  Some Linux distributions use musl libc as main libc (OpenWRT, Alpine Linux (used by official Docker images))
1.  Some other Linux distributions proposole musl as an alternative libc (Gentoo, Debian)

So "glibc defines the linux API" seems more like a personal opinion than a fact.
Usually, sticking with standards (POSIX, XPG etc) is best to avoid issues.

Critical error: gimp_line_art_thaw: assertion 'line_art->priv->frozen' failed
Fails to build with musl

note.body:
Some of the comments here have been less than productive.

It's not true that musl "only implements POSIX". We have policy for what extensions we support, based on a lot of criteria including possible conflicting definitions, usefulness, costs (implementation, maintenance, runtime, etc.) and other things. Generally when an extension has few or no users (note: GNOME vte is the only software that's ever been reported to have a problem with lack of the W_EXITCODE extension), we try to get the non-portable code using it fixed before even considering adding the extension.

The "glibc defines the linux API" viewpoint is completely unacceptable for us. In some aspects the interfaces defined by glibc are outright wrong (contrary to specification in standards). In others they introduce complex interfactions (or just dependencies) between components that result in failure conditions that should not exist or just significant code size or runtime cost. If these kinds of things were deemed acceptable, musl would never have been created. Accepting the systemd view here would essentially give systemd editorial control over what is or is not included in musl, and that's contrary to project goals and policy mentioned above.

Now, regardless of whether GNOME folks agree with "glibc defines the linux API" or not, it's irrelevant, because GNOME is not Linux-only software. If you want to consider us non-Linux, that's perfectly fine; this is still a portability bug.

If there's a good reason you believe W_EXITCODE should be included, aside from "glibc does it", we're always welcome to hearing that and discussing it. Extensions that actually allow you to do something useful that would not be possible in a portable way, and that don't incur costs, can often be reasonable to add.

By the way, last time there was a case of an application doing weird and nonportable things with the W* macros from wait.h, it turned out to be a real bug -- they were encoding special values in a way that wasn't compatible with the MIPS sigset_t being twice as large as other archs'. So there is also value to catching non-portable usage via diversity of implementation and strict interpretation of standards, even in areas as simple as the W* macros.

note.body: Current fixes are indeed working for **Night Light**, but there's still an issue with **gamma ramp size too small: 0** for [gnomerr](https://aur.archlinux.org/packages/redshift-gnomerr-git/). I do realize that **gnomerr** isn't an official GNOME thing (at least I think it isn't), so this is more a FYI. The code lives at https://github.com/prahal/redshift/tree/add-gnomerr-method and is basically [redshift](https://github.com/jonls/redshift) patched to work on Wayland. It offers support for a smoother/more gradual transition between day and night screen temperature, something which is lacking in Night Light. Probably not the best place to add feature requests for GNOME Night Light, but that would be a nice addition. Also starting Night Light as early as possible in the login sequence, to avoid abrupt screen changes would give NL a more polished feel IMHO.

note.body:
Thanks @desiderantes for suggestion. Mine solution still meets most of my specific criteria. Yours would work as long as there could be a specific sequence defined in a key. Mine works better as there can be repeated occurrences of an identifier in a template. And it will work regardless of number of these occurrences.

I was probably misunderstood due to my own fault. I tried to mark my issue as ~"1. Enhancement" (which doesn't show in the issues list). Instead I should probably marked it as ~"1. Feature" for feature request.

My rationale is simple - enabling template strings to be loaded from a variable at runtime and then parsed would enable more flexibility in dynamic content creation and manipulation. At the same time I see little obstacles when it comes to possibility of such modification of template strings' behavior. I may be wrong, but if it works with printf should work with template strings as well. There are solutions like template-glib, but are feature heavy and not suited for simple string substitutions.

note.body:
So, t seems that this fix can get you trapped in a really nasty loop if epiphany is set as that default ftp handler!
I experienced this with 3.34.3.1 on Fedora 31: setting epiphany as my default Web app through the graphical Gnome settings -> Default applications seems to also set it as your default ftp handler (not sure about this part), but somehow epiphany became that default app on my system. With that, whenever you click on an ftp link you're stuck in an endless loop of opening/closing tabs, which is extremely hard to get out (because the window regains focus all the time, the only solution I could find was to send it to a different workspace to be able to use the terminal to kill the process).

events.target_title: consider implementing new xterm SGR stack

note.body: I created an account here just to come file this issue, and found it was already here. What will it take to get this implemented? Do we just need a person to write the code (could be me?), or is there a decision-making / approval process we need to go through first? (who does the "considering" mentioned in the issue title?)

events.target_title: consider implementing new xterm SGR stack

note.body:
> whether the is protocol already in use in a terminal application, or which application would use it

Unfortunately I do not have any publicly-available/open-source code to showcase this, but re: "which problem this solves" I have found it very useful. The problem is composability of content.

I was writing code that emits text that contains SGR control sequences to colorize it. However, I found that my text was not easily composable--that is, I may have a format string like `"The name is: %s, the position is: %s"`, and then I want to `sprintf` some inserts into that. Then that whole string I may want to insert into another, and so forth. The problem is that to have SGR sequences in that one has to have sort of a global awareness of content and associated coloring for that to work out.

With SGR push/pop, though, I can do things like:

    <fgBlack>   : CSI 3 0 m
    <fgGreen>   : CSI 3 2 m
    <fgYellow>  : CSI 3 3 m
    <fgMagenta> : CSI 3 5 m
    <fgWhite>   : CSI 3 7 m
    <bgBlack>   : CSI 4 0 m
    <bgYellow>  : CSI 4 3 m
    <bgWhite>   : CSI 4 7 m
    <pushSgr>   : CSI # {
    <popSgr>    : CSI # }

    name = "Dan <pushSgr><fgBlack><bgWhite>Thompson<popSgr>"
    position = "<pushSgr><fgMagenta><bgYellow>Developer at Large<popSgr>"
    line1 = "<pushSgr><bgBlack><fgWhite>The name is: %s, the position is: %s<popSgr>"

And then I can `printf(line1, name, position)`, and have it all work out.

Without a push/pop mechanism, composing strings like that cannot be done that way at all, unless you do your own custom rendering pass to handle the pushes and pops.

I personally have not utilized the ability to save and restore individual video attributes; my "composability" scenario means I just want to save / restore them all. (In other words, even if VTE only implemented "CSI # {" (and "CSI # }", of course) and did not permit specifying any parameters, it would still be very useful for me.)

events.target_title: consider implementing new xterm SGR stack

note.body:
> jazzdelightsme: Is what was merged in xterm what your original patch did, or if not what changed before it was merged?

My original patch was pretty simple, and only supported plain "push" and "pop" (because that's all I needed to solve my composability problem). And I implemented them as just more SGR codes, 66 for push and 67 for pop. (IIRC, I went to the trouble of looking up whatever ISO/ECMA/ANSI/WHATEVER spec those codes are standardized in, and pulled 66 and 67 from unused spectrum, or OEM-reserved spectrum, or something like that.)

Thomas added the ability to only save specified states (and doubtless cleaned my code up to fit better). And he switched from SGR codes to the "#{", "#}" codes. I don't know / never asked why; I assumed he had reasons. It's one thing for some rando on the internet (me) to show a demo using "reserved" SGR spectrum, and another thing entirely to ship it in a widely-used, standard tool. I assumed it was just safer for him to pick a totally new sequence.

In fact, it looks like I left a diff on github which is [still there](https://github.com/ThomasDickey/xterm-snapshots/compare/master...jazzdelightsme:user/danthom/demoPushPopSgr?expand=1).

I lean toward's Martin's side about not mixing push/pop with state change (it seems like overkill), but as long as there is still a way to do plain push and plain pop without changing state, I won't complain either way.

events.target_title: consider implementing new xterm SGR stack

note.body:
> (I'm starting to somewhat question whether we need this saving/restoring thingy at all. It's already too much trouble.)

<<SadPanda.gif>>

I certainly don't want to cause trouble, but I do find push/pop to be fantastically useful.

I'd like to lobby for option B:

> B) Use the same sequence, ignore the entire sequence in presence of numeric parameters (that is: nop unless there are no params)

This provides a way forward without getting entangled with xterm/vte impedance mismatch. People who require the partial stuff will still have to use xterm; people who just want the basic case now have their world significantly opened up (to either xterm or vte), and I think at that point, it has the possibility of actually becoming a standard thing.

If you ever get anybody coming along who says "hey, I want to do the partial save/restore in vte", you can at that point decide what to do with the stuff that doesn't mesh well. (My supposition is that day might never, ever come...) Even if that day does come, you could still say "not worth the trouble; stick to xterm", but everybody else would still have the standard, useful full push/pop.

events.target_title: consider implementing new xterm SGR stack

note.body:
> Did anybody properly invite him to terminal-wg?

I don't know anything about terminal-wg. I found something that looked like it could be it ([here](https://lists.freedesktop.org/mailman/listinfo/terminal-wg)), but the archive page makes it appear empty... perhaps it is something else?

> But i think it's important to talk to each other here. Ideally via terminal-wg or if needed per direct mail. Also we really need voices from application developers.

I'm wondering if anybody else has communicated with Thomas at all. I've just realized that the use of curly brackets in the control sequence is going to be a big problem in C# (or other languages that use curly brackets in formatting). The problem is that C# format strings use curly brackets to denote replacements (like `"The name is {0}, the position is {1}."`). Curly brackets that are not used to denote an insert must be escaped (by doubling up the brackets). The problem is: how do you know if it needs to be escaped or not? As text is being composed, you do not know when your particular snippet of text is going to be formatted as part of some larger string. For an analog in C, imagine if the percent character (`%`) were used in the control sequence. If the string is going to be used with `sprintf`, you'll need to double it (`%%`), but you must *not* do it if it will not be. It's disastrous.

So I don't know about terminal-wg, but I would be happy to contact Thomas about this if there is not already a conversation with him somewhere.

events.target_title: consider implementing new xterm SGR stack
consider implementing new xterm SGR stack

note.body:
FYI, Thomas has made some updates in this area in xterm patch [#345](https://invisible-island.net/xterm/xterm.log.html#xterm_345):

* fix a special case in XTPOPSGR where direct-colors were not checked as a dependency of indexed-colors, contrary to documentation.
* add vttests/sgrPushPop2.pl to illustrate how selective pushes work, as well as to demonstrate push/pop of the various color types supported by xterm.
* add aliases for the sgr push/pop controls to work around language limitations of C#

(The aliases added are CSI+"#p" for push and CSI+"#q" for pop.)

I'm still in favor of deferring support for selective push/pop if we need to reduce the "activation energy" required to get a useful change into vte.

After my switch to wayland everything worked fine for a time, but then non-wayland apps (like chromium and gvim) started to use something other than gnome layout settings. (I have us,ru,ua layout in gnome, and chromium was using ua,us - and i was unable to find from where this settings is loaded)

Removed from desktop xorg-xinput xorg-xkbevd, restarted session and now chromium is picking up gnome layout just fine.

note.body:
I ran into this too. 

I noticed the bug only appears if there is only one draft. If there is a second one in the drafts folder then geary manages to save without issue.

Steps to reliably reproduce the bug :

1. Open geary
1. Create a new draft/delete all except one draft
1. Enter something in the body or a to:address
1. Save and close the draft
1. Open the draft again and type some more
1. wait 10 seconds
1. Geary tries to save the draft and the draft disappears
![image](/uploads/abe2aa1363a6b6e2e8bf23008f777a49/image.png)
1. Clicking anywhere else (navigating away from the already closed draft) opens this window -

Testing for some ore edge cases I did end up with a ghost draft. ie draft folder had a 1 on it but nothing in there when I opened the drafts folder. Haven't been able to reproduce that one yet.

I am on 3.32

note.body:
I want to contribute gjs and this issue seems a good point to start. I have looked the code and currently found two member functions that can be marked as const. However, I am not sure about couple things:
1.  Should I mark every parameter as `const` if it is not modified in the function?
2.  Should I look for parameters of `static` functions to mark as `const`?
3.  What should I do if something is passed to another function that takes parameter as non-`const` but also doesn't modify? Should mark the parameters as `const` all the way down?

events.target_title: Ensure const-correctness in C++ objects

note.body:
First of all, thanks for your answers.

In the `toggle.h` the function `ToggleQueue::is_queued` essentially doesn't modify anything but since it uses `std::lock_guard` (I guess to be thread safe) it can't be marked as `const`. I have done some search in Google and found [this thread](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/48133164/how-to-use-a-stdlock-guard-without-violating-const-correctness). I don't have in-depth knowledge but I think we could mark at least this function as `const` if we mark the `lock` as `mutable`. But I don't know if we should do it.

events.target_title: Wacom pressure feel is misleading / difficult to set

note.body:
> how useful is it to make fine adjustments from GNOME instead of the application

It can be useful, because I don't think this is the role of applications to setup a global pressure curve *per devices* (or to setup the device mapping at all, imo). On my practise of digital art, I'm rarely using only a single tablet. My O.S.connects to three tablets (one for travel, one pen display for drawing, one traditional flat large for speedpainting). They all have various built-in pressure curves and styluses tech. Also, their styluses become softer and softer for pressure with time.

![calibrating_pressure-08-my-curves_revoy](/uploads/c8d1b016f4cf3bda733532867b6c6e34/calibrating_pressure-08-my-curves_revoy.jpg)

Here is an example of how I used to configure two previous tablet I owned from Krita settings (global curves for software). The first one for the intuos compensated its stylus being too old (it was necessary to make it more 'firm' to get the various pressure range). The second one was about the Cintiq21UX where I put the max pressure reaching at 75% of physical pressure on the device; something I did to not scratch my device using too firm pressure on the surface. I wrote an article a while ago with example like that; 'calibrating pressure' ; https://www.davidrevoy.com/article182/calibrating-wacom-stylus-pressure-on-krita

events.target_title: Wacom pressure feel is misleading / difficult to set

note.body:
Personally, I'm a zero configuration runner. I don't really change the curves. I would test draw a few strokes and adjust myself to the current device. For my usecase this option doesn't matter at all.

I do see David's point of assigning different curves to different tablets or even pens. However, I would like to disagree with @Jehan about not implementing curves inside the drawing applications: Krita can assign curves to both global and EACH brush presets. It makes so much sense to do it that way -- it enables different curves for different devices and different virtual tools. I think that's absolutely necessary for an advanced painting application. A single system-wide curve simply cannot replace such a function. It is also the reason I stopped using system-wide curves altogether since I switched to Krita.

And then there is also this one: the more professional a user is, the more likely they are using the Cintiq/Intuos4/5/Pro lines which share the same stylus and digitizer. The same pen can be used across every device -- and thus no more different curves between different devices. I would argue it is beneficial for artists to keep their workflow as simple as possible. I can't handle changing pens when going between my pen display to my tablet. It's maddening.

All and all, I think only a very small number of people would benefit from this improvement. It has no downside other than putting your development time into it. But thank you for considering more options for us. You never know when you gonna need them, that's for sure!

P.S. Also, maybe suggest a KEY MISSING FEATURE from Gnome's Wacom configuration? A switch to turn off the touch sensitivity, permanently! The new highend Wacom devices are all touch sensitive now, and under Gnome I can only stop their madness by writing scripts and assign them at start up. Not all users can do that, so providing a GUI for that would be a god-sent. Thank you!

I'll appreciate it greatly when the GNOME team implements this!

My suggestion for the specific functionality is to emulate Cinnamon's behaviour:

events.target_title: TopIcon Plus makes GS consume 40-50% cpu time

note.body:
A can confirm that mutter!270 is a workaround for the problem. I installed it on Ubuntu 19.04 with the following process.
* Create a working directory e.g mutter
* If apt sources are not enabled, enable it in software-properties-gtk
* go to your working dir and run the following: `apt source mutter`
* install build dependencies: `apt build-dep mutter`
* `cd mutter-3.32.0+git20190410/debian`
* edit changlelog -> change the last number in the top line e.g to ...ubuntu2
* edit rules file -> comment out $(TEST_COMMAND) line(s)
* go to patches folder
* download the diff file: `wget https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/mutter/merge_requests/270.diff`
* add the diff into series file: `echo "270.diff" >>series`
* go to your working directory root
* build your new deb packages: `dpkg-buildpackage -b`
* install packages: `dpkg -i gir1.2-mutter-4_3.32.0+git20190410-1ubuntu2_amd64.deb libmutter-4-0_3.32.0+git20190410-1ubuntu2_amd64.deb mutter-common_3.32.0+git20190410-1ubuntu2_all.deb mutter_3.32.0+git20190410-1ubuntu2_amd64.deb`

events.target_title: Ctrl + F search disengages immediately after CTRL + F pressed

note.body:
It is unnecessary to type ctrl-F in order to do a search. Instead, you simply start type anything (except ctrl-F) to do a search once GNOME software is launched. However, I suspect you're right that ctrl-F should just display the search box, instead of the behavior you're reporting.

In this case, I'm not a big fan of hiding features like search where you can't even tell there is a search feature without pressing keys in an interface that appears to exclusively mouse-driven.

I do value not wasting screen space (especially in the web browser), but in this case, I'd rather the search-feature be **explicitly shown**; nothing is more intuitive than simply showing a labeled search box.

events.target_title: No weather information

note.body:
This might be the same as issue #4 

I think that the problem is that the app gets it's information from the Norwegian Meteorological Institute [1] which either seems to lack information on many cities or I think that maybe there is a problem with the language barrier and queries for certain cities are not resolved correctly. 

As you can see in the screenshots below, requesting information about Oslo, capital city of Norway, works perfectly while Buenos Aires, capital of Argentina, or Madrid, capital of Spain do not. 

Furthermore, I went online to the NWI page and manually searched for Buenos Aires and Palma and it said "Found nowhere with this name". I was unable to spell Sao Paulo correctly for lack of the special character for the "o", but I'm guessing a search on the site by someone who can type that character won't work either, even if the app actually recognizes the Sao Paulo and has shown me the forecast for it.

The problem I find is that this app ships with the standard Manjaro distro I'm using and it is really well integrated to the gnome hud and calendar. I'd really like to use it (for Buenos Aires). 

I hope this helps to find a solution to this issue quickly. It looks like it has been happening for a while. If I can do more to help, let me know. 

Thanks to the team!

PS: I've been having this issue for days. However, as I was writing this comment, momentarily it seemed to find PART of Buenos Aires' forecast. Only for a moment and now it's gone. Oh well, screenshot below.

Screenshots:

![About](/uploads/4563aee536b2608799e7fc4173f87988/About.png)

![BuenosAiresforecastmissing](/uploads/5b6ff0d3f965353bdf39c57c909c83ea/BuenosAiresforecastmissing.png)

![Osloforecast](/uploads/0a1aa2c551b0391ac09daeb8225f62c0/Osloforecast.png)

![BuenosAiresforecast](/uploads/fdd4ca6d7660ec7eeeee3cd58d094d52/BuenosAiresforecast.png)



[1] Norwegian Meteorological Institute

events.target_title: No weather information

note.body:
I just tried looking for Buenos Aires on yr.no [1] and you are correct. Buenos Aires appears normally, so the data must be there.

Yesterday, I used the NWI page [2] directly, and if you try looking there, you'll see that Buenos Aires is "Found nowhere with this name". 

So, I agree with you in that it is probably an issue with query. I still think there could be something about language that is preventing the data from being properly used. Otherwise, why would some information work and not other? I hope this helps. 

A workaround: Choose an available location nearby.
Finally, yesterday I found a compromise solution. While the information for the city was not found by the app, the information on the city's international airport  was (Ezeiza international airport -screenshots below). It's located about 30 kms away, so it the information is not 100% accurate for my location (at the moment of this writing it says it is "sunny" but here it's cloudy), but it is good enough to use while a more permanent solution comes through.

Screenshots:
Buenos Aires Found in Yr.no
![yyrbuenosairespresent](/uploads/3256648ca72e1b7af5e41cf49687e240/yyrbuenosairespresent.png)

Buenos Aires NOT found on the Norwegian Meterological Institute Site
![NWIbuenosaires](/uploads/d609b25e46e6a1e2518212f578fbabeb/NWIbuenosaires.png)

Near Location Workaround (Ezeiza Airport)
![Ezeizaworkaround](/uploads/79149056f7f0c3702fb71705b347c877/Ezeizaworkaround.png)
![gnomecalendarwithweatherworking](/uploads/4c01345654c5a3c618f905f45eeef042/gnomecalendarwithweatherworking.png)

Ezeiza works while other parts of the same city do not.
![otherplacesnotworking](/uploads/def2ac7e9cfd4a2b1e5ef6a2be71f731/otherplacesnotworking.png)

Thank you!

[1](https://www.yr.no/?spr=eng)
[2](https://www.met.no/)

note.body:
If anyone else comes across this: 
VSCode doesn't support fractional scaling because electron (the framework it's build on) doesn't support it, which doesn't support fractional scaling because chromium doesn't support it (the web engine it's based on). 

Here is the vs code issue to track progress: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/72759
And this is the chromium issue to track progress: https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=578890

So how do I find out who is to ask?

events.target_title: Not working on 19.04

note.body:
I'm not the reporter, so I'm not sure he's talking about the same extension, but since upgrading to Ubuntu 19.04 this week-end, the "Places Status Indicator" is not working anymore. See also the last comments on https://extensions.gnome.org/extension/8/places-status-indicator/.

Looking Glass displays the following repeated several times:

```
TypeError: this._create is not a function
TypeError: _indicator is not a function
```

events.target_title: Not working on 19.04

note.body:
So, it seems this is caused by the `_create()` method being invoked before it is defined in https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell-extensions/blob/master/extensions/places-menu/extension.js#L119.

I edited `~/.local/share/gnome-shell/extensions/places-menu@gnome-shell-extensions.gcampax.github.com/extension.js` to move the `_create()` definition at the top of the class, before `_init` which invokes it, and after reloading the shell (Altf+F2, r), the "Places" menu now appears ans seems functional...
